generalfeedback.text:
1. Note that \(x\) is a common factor of both terms. Thus

    \[ {@a1@}x^2 + x = x({@a1@}x + 1). \]

  2. First note the coefficient of \(x^2\) in this case is \({@b1@}\). Multiply the whole expression by this number and rearrange as follows: 

    \[ {@b1@}({@b1@}x^2 + {@b1+1@}x + 1) = {@b1@}({@b1@}x^2) + {@b1@}({@1+b1@})x + {@b1@}(1) = ({@b1@}x)^2 + {@1+b1@}({@b1@}x)  + {@b1@}. \] 

    We now introduce a new variable \(z\) such that \(z = {@b1@}x\). Thus we can write 

    \[ ({@b1@}x)^2 + {@1+b1@}({@b1@}x)  + {@b1@} \text{ as } z^2 + {@1+b1@}z + {@b1@}. \] 

    This can be factorised to give \( (z + {@b1@})(z + 1\). Returning to the original variable by replacing \(z\) by \({@b1@}x\) we find

     \[  {@b1@}({@b1@}x^2 + {@b1+1@}x + 1) = ({@b1@}x + {@b1@})({@b1@}x + 1) \] 

    A factor of \({@b1@}\) can be extracted from the first bracket on the right so that 

    \[ {@b1@}({@b1@}x^2 + {@b1+1@}x + 1)  = {@b1@}(x + 1)({@b1@}x + 1), \] 

    so that 

    \[ {@b1@}x^2 + {@b1+1@}x + 1 = (x + 1)({@b1@}x + 1). \]

  3. First note the coefficient of \(x^2\) in this case is \({@c1*c2@}\). Multiply the whole expression by this number and rearrange as follows: 

    \[ {@c1*c2@}({@c1*c2@}x^2 + {@c1+c2@}x + 1) = {@c1*c2@}({@c1*c2@}x^2) + {@c1*c2@}({@c1+c2@})x - {@c1*c2@}(1) = ({@c1*c2@}x)^2 + {@c1+c2@} ({@c1*c2@}x)  - {@c1*c2@}. \] 

    We now introduce a new variable \(z\) such that \(z = {@c1*c2@}x\). Thus we can write 

    \[ ({@c1*c2@}x)^2 + {@c1+c2@} ({@c1*c2@}x)  - {@c1*c2@} \text{ as } z^2 +{@c1+c2@} z - {@c1*c2@}. \]

    This can be factorised to give \( (z + {@c1@})(z + {@c2@})\). Returning to the original variable by replacing \(z\) by \({@c@}x\) we find

    \[ {@c1*c2@}({@c1*c2@}x^2 + {@c1+c2@}x + 1) = ({@c1*c2@}x + {@c1@})({@c1*c2@}x + {@c2@}). \]

    A factor of \({@c1@}\) can be extracted from the first bracket on the right, and a factor of \({@c2@}\) can be extracted from the second bracket on the right, so that

    \[ {@c1*c2@}({@c1*c2@}x^2 + {@c1+c2@}x + 1) = {@c1*c2@}({@c2@}x + 1)({@c1@}x + 1), \]

    so that

    \[ {@c1*c2@}x^2 + {@c1+c2@}x + 1 = ({@c2@}x + 1)({@c1@}x + 1). \]

  4. First note the coefficient of \(x^2\) in this case is \({@d1*d2@}\). Multiply the whole expression by this number and rearrange as follows:

    \[ {@d1*d2@}({@d1*d2@}x^2 + {@d1*d3+d2*d4@}x + {@d3*d4@}) = {@d1*d2@}({@d1*d2@}x^2) + {@d1*d2@}({@d1*d3+d2*d4@})x + {@d1*d2@}({@d3*d4@}) = ({@d1*d2@}x)^2 + {@d1*d3+d2*d4@} ({@d1*d2@}x) + {@d1*d2*d3*d4@}. \]

    We now introduce a new variable \(z\) such that \(z = {@d1*d2@}x\). Thus we can write

    \[ ({@d1*d2@}x)^2 + {@d1*d3+d2*d4@} ({@d1*d2@}x) + {@d1*d2*d3*d4@} \text{ as } z^2 +{@d1*d3+d2*d4@} z + {@d1*d2*d3*d4@}. \]

    This can be factorised to give \( (z + {@d1*d3@})(z + {@d2*d4@})\). Returning to the original variable by replacing \(z\) by \({@d1*d2@}x\) we find

    \[ {@d1*d2@}({@d1*d2@}x^2 + {@d1*d3+d2*d4@}x + {@d3*d4@}) = ({@d1*d2@}x + {@d1*d3@})({@d1*d2@}x + {@d2*d4@}) \]

    A factor of \({@d1@}\) can be extracted from the first bracket on the right, and a factor of \({@d2@}\) can be extracted from the second bracket on the right, so that/p>

    \[ {@d1*d2@}({@d1*d2@}x^2 + {@d1*d3+d2*d4@}x + {@d3*d4@}) =({@d1*d2@}({@d2@}x + {@d3@})({@d1@}x + {@d4@}) \]

    so that

    \[ {@d1*d2@}x^2 + {@d1*d3+d2*d4@}x + {@d3*d4@} = ({@d2@}x + {@d3@})({@d1@}x + {@d4@}). \]

  5. First note the coefficient of \(x^2\) in this case is \({@e1*e2@}\). Multiply the whole expression by this number and rearrange as follows:

    \[ {@e1*e2@}({@e1*e2@}x^2 + {@-e1*e4+e2*e3@}x - {@e3*e4@}) = {@e1*e2@}({@e1*e2@}x^2) + {@e1*e2@}({@-e1*e4+e2*e3@})x - {@e1*e2@}({@e3*e4@}) = ({@e1*e2@}x)^2 + {@-e1*e4+e2*e3@} ({@e1*e2@}x)- {@e1*e2*e3*e4@}. \]

    We now introduce a new variable \(z\) such that \(z = {@e1*e2@}x\). Thus we can write

    \[ ({@e1*e2@}x)^2 + {@-e1*e4+e2*e3@} ({@e1*e2@}x) - {@e1*e2*e3*e4@} \text{ as } z^2 +{@-e1*e4+e2*e3@} z - {@e1*e2*e3*e4@}. \]

    This can be factorised to give \( (z - {@e1*e4@})(z + {@e2*e3@})\). Returning to the original variable by replacing \(z\) by \({@e1*e2@}x\) we find

    \[ {@e1*e2@}({@e1*e2@}x^2 + {@-e1*e4+e2*e3@}x - {@e3*e4@}) = ({@e1*e2@}x - {@e1*e4@})({@e1*e2@}x + {@e2*e3@}) \]

    A factor of \({@e1@}\) can be extracted from the first bracket on the right, and a factor of \({@e2@}\) can be extracted from the second bracket on the right, so that

    \[ {@e1*e2@}({@e1*e2@}x^2 + {@-e1*e4+e2*e3@}x - {@e3*e4@}) =({@e1*e2@}({@e2@}x - {@e4@})({@e1@}x + {@e3@}) \]

    so that

    \[ {@e1*e2@}x^2 + {@-e1*e4+e2*e3@}x - {@e3*e4@} = ({@e2@}x - {@e4@})({@e1@}x + {@e3@}). \]

  6. First note the coefficient of \(x^2\) in this case is \({@-f1@}\). Multiply the whole expression by this number and rearrange as follows:

    \[ {@-f1@}({@-f1@}x^2 + {@f3 - f1@}x + {@f3@}) = {@-f1@}({@-f1@}x^2) {@-f1@}({@f3 -f1@})x + {@-f1@}({@f3@} = ({@f1@}x)^2 -{@f3 -f1@}({@f1@}x) - {@f1*f3@}. \]

    We now introduce a new variable \(z\) such that \(z = {@f1@}x\). Thus we can write

    \[ ({@f1@}x)^2 -{@f3 -f1@}({@f1@}x); - {@f1*f3@} \text{ as } z^2 -{@f3 -f1@}z - {@f1*f3@}. \]

    This can be factorised to give \( (z + {@f1@})(z - {@f3@}\). Returning to the original variable by replacing \(z\) by \({@f1@}x\) we find

    \[ {@-f1@}({@-f1@}x^2 + {@f3 - f1@}x + {@f3@}) = ({@f1@}x + {@f1@})({@f1@}x - {@f3@}) \]

    A factor of \({@f1@}\) can be extracted from the first bracket on the right, and a factor of /(-1/) can be extracted from the second bracket on the right so that

    \[ {@-f1@}({@-f1@}x^2 + {@f3 - f1@}x + {@f3@}) = -{@f1@}(x + 1)(-{@f1@}x + {@f3@}), \]

    so that

    \[ {@-f1@}x^2 + {@f3 - f1@}x + {@f3@} = (x + 1)(-{@f1@}x + {@f3@}). \]

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

falsefeedback.text:
Note that \(x\) is a common factor of both terms. Thus

\[ {@a1@}x^2 + x = x({@a1@}x + 1). \]

First note the coefficient of \(x^2\) in this case is \({@b1@}\). Multiply the whole expression by this number and rearrange as follows: 

\[ {@b1@}({@b1@}x^2 + {@b1+1@}x + 1) = {@b1@}({@b1@}x^2) + {@b1@}({@1+b1@})x + {@b1@}(1) = ({@b1@}x)^2 + {@1+b1@}({@b1@}x)  + {@b1@}. \] 

We now introduce a new variable \(z\) such that \(z = {@b1@}x\). Thus we can write 

\[ ({@b1@}x)^2 + {@1+b1@}({@b1@}x)  + {@b1@} \text{ as } z^2 + {@1+b1@}z + {@b1@}. \] 

This can be factorised to give \( (z + {@b1@})(z + 1\). Returning to the original variable by replacing \(z\) by \({@b1@}x\) we find

 \[  {@b1@}({@b1@}x^2 + {@b1+1@}x + 1) = ({@b1@}x + {@b1@})({@b1@}x + 1) \] 

A factor of \({@b1@}\) can be extracted from the first bracket on the right so that 

\[ {@b1@}({@b1@}x^2 + {@b1+1@}x + 1)  = {@b1@}(x + 1)({@b1@}x + 1), \] 

so that 

\[ {@b1@}x^2 + {@b1+1@}x + 1 = (x + 1)({@b1@}x + 1). \]

First note the coefficient of \(x^2\) in this case is \({@c1*c2@}\). Multiply the whole expression by this number and rearrange as follows: 

\[ {@c1*c2@}({@c1*c2@}x^2 + {@c1+c2@}x + 1) = {@c1*c2@}({@c1*c2@}x^2) + {@c1*c2@}({@c1+c2@})x - {@c1*c2@}(1) = ({@c1*c2@}x)^2 + {@c1+c2@} ({@c1*c2@}x)  - {@c1*c2@}. \] 

We now introduce a new variable \(z\) such that \(z = {@c1*c2@}x\). Thus we can write 

\[ ({@c1*c2@}x)^2 + {@c1+c2@} ({@c1*c2@}x)  - {@c1*c2@} \text{ as } z^2 +{@c1+c2@} z - {@c1*c2@}. \] 

This can be factorised to give \( (z + {@c1@})(z + {@c2@})\). Returning to the original variable by replacing \(z\) by \({@c@}x\) we find

 \[ {@c1*c2@}({@c1*c2@}x^2 + {@c1+c2@}x + 1)  =  ({@c1*c2@}x + {@c1@})({@c1*c2@}x + {@c2@}). \] 

A factor of \({@c1@}\) can be extracted from the first bracket on the right, and  a factor of \({@c2@}\) can be extracted from the second bracket on the right, so that 

\[ {@c1*c2@}({@c1*c2@}x^2 + {@c1+c2@}x + 1)   = {@c1*c2@}({@c2@}x + 1)({@c1@}x + 1), \] 

so that 

\[ {@c1*c2@}x^2 + {@c1+c2@}x + 1 =  ({@c2@}x + 1)({@c1@}x + 1). \]

First note the coefficient of \(x^2\) in this case is \({@d1*d2@}\). Multiply the whole expression by this number and rearrange as follows: 

\[ {@d1*d2@}({@d1*d2@}x^2 + {@d1*d3+d2*d4@}x + {@d3*d4@}) = {@d1*d2@}({@d1*d2@}x^2) + {@d1*d2@}({@d1*d3+d2*d4@})x + {@d1*d2@}({@d3*d4@}) = ({@d1*d2@}x)^2 + {@d1*d3+d2*d4@} ({@d1*d2@}x)  + {@d1*d2*d3*d4@}. \] 

We now introduce a new variable \(z\) such that \(z = {@d1*d2@}x\). Thus we can write 

\[ ({@d1*d2@}x)^2 + {@d1*d3+d2*d4@} ({@d1*d2@}x)  + {@d1*d2*d3*d4@} \text{ as } z^2 +{@d1*d3+d2*d4@} z + {@d1*d2*d3*d4@}. \] 

This can be factorised to give \( (z + {@d1*d3@})(z + {@d2*d4@})\). Returning to the original variable by replacing \(z\) by \({@d1*d2@}x\) we find

 \[ {@d1*d2@}({@d1*d2@}x^2 + {@d1*d3+d2*d4@}x + {@d3*d4@}) = ({@d1*d2@}x + {@d1*d3@})({@d1*d2@}x + {@d2*d4@}) \] 

A factor of \({@d1@}\) can be extracted from the first bracket on the right, and a factor of \({@d2@}\) can be extracted from the second bracket on the right, so that 

\[ {@d1*d2@}({@d1*d2@}x^2 + {@d1*d3+d2*d4@}x + {@d3*d4@})  =({@d1*d2@}({@d2@}x + {@d3@})({@d1@}x + {@d4@}) \] 

so that 

\[ {@d1*d2@}x^2 + {@d1*d3+d2*d4@}x + {@d3*d4@} = ({@d2@}x + {@d3@})({@d1@}x + {@d4@}). \]

First note the coefficient of \(x^2\) in this case is \({@e1*e2@}\). Multiply the whole expression by this number and rearrange as follows: 

\[ {@e1*e2@}({@e1*e2@}x^2 + {@-e1*e4+e2*e3@}x - {@e3*e4@}) = {@e1*e2@}({@e1*e2@}x^2) + {@e1*e2@}({@-e1*e4+e2*e3@})x - {@e1*e2@}({@e3*e4@}) = ({@e1*e2@}x)^2 + {@-e1*e4+e2*e3@} ({@e1*e2@}x)  - {@e1*e2*e3*e4@}. \] 

We now introduce a new variable \(z\) such that \(z = {@e1*e2@}x\). Thus we can write 

\[ ({@e1*e2@}x)^2 + {@-e1*e4+e2*e3@} ({@e1*e2@}x)  - {@e1*e2*e3*e4@} \text{ as } z^2 +{@-e1*e4+e2*e3@} z  - {@e1*e2*e3*e4@}. \] 

This can be factorised to give \( (z - {@e1*e4@})(z + {@e2*e3@})\). Returning to the original variable by replacing \(z\) by \({@e1*e2@}x\) we find

 \[  {@e1*e2@}({@e1*e2@}x^2 + {@-e1*e4+e2*e3@}x - {@e3*e4@}) = ({@e1*e2@}x - {@e1*e4@})({@e1*e2@}x + {@e2*e3@}) \] 

A factor of \({@e1@}\) can be extracted from the first bracket on the right, and a factor of \({@e2@}\) can be extracted from the second bracket on the right, so that 

\[  {@e1*e2@}({@e1*e2@}x^2 + {@-e1*e4+e2*e3@}x - {@e3*e4@})  =({@e1*e2@}({@e2@}x - {@e4@})({@e1@}x + {@e3@}) \] 

so that 

\[ {@e1*e2@}x^2 + {@-e1*e4+e2*e3@}x - {@e3*e4@} = ({@e2@}x - {@e4@})({@e1@}x + {@e3@}). \]

First note the coefficient of \(x^2\) in this case is \({@-f1@}\). Multiply the whole expression by this number and rearrange as follows: 

\[ {@-f1@}({@-f1@}x^2 + {@f3 - f1@}x + {@f3@}) = {@-f1@}({@-f1@}x^2)  {@-f1@}({@f3 -f1@})x + {@-f1@}({@f3@} = ({@f1@}x)^2 - {@f3 -f1@}({@f1@}x)  - {@f1*f3@}. \] 

We now introduce a new variable \(z\) such that \(z = {@f1@}x\). Thus we can write 

\[ ({@f1@}x)^2 - {@f3 -f1@}({@f1@}x)  - {@f1*f3@} \text{ as } z^2 - {@f3 -f1@}z - {@f1*f3@}. \] 

This can be factorised to give \( (z + {@f1@})(z - {@f3@}\). Returning to the original variable by replacing \(z\) by \({@f1@}x\) we find

 \[  {@-f1@}({@-f1@}x^2 + {@f3 - f1@}x + {@f3@}) = ({@f1@}x + {@f1@})({@f1@}x - {@f3@}) \] 

A factor of \({@f1@}\) can be extracted from the first bracket on the right, and a factor of /(-1/) can be extracted from the second bracket on the right so that 

\[  {@-f1@}({@-f1@}x^2 + {@f3 - f1@}x + {@f3@})  =  -{@f1@}(x + 1)(-{@f1@}x + {@f3@}), \] 

so that 

\[ {@-f1@}x^2 + {@f3 - f1@}x + {@f3@} = (x + 1)(-{@f1@}x + {@f3@}). \]
